definition: Song Jiaoren (1882-1913), politician of the revolutionary party involved in the 1911 Xinhai revolution, murdered in Shanghai in 1913
surname Song/the Song dynasty (960-1279)/also Song of the Southern dynasties 南朝宋 (420-479)
surname Jiao
to teach
religion/teaching/to make/to cause/to tell
humane/kernel
Huang Xing (1874-1916), revolutionary politician, close collaborator of Sun Yat-sen, prominent in the 1911 Xinhai Revolution 辛亥革命[Xin1 hai4 Ge2 ming4], murdered in Shanghai in 1916
Tang Shaoyi (1862-1939), politician and diplomat
Wang Ching-wei (1883-1944), left-wing Guomingdang politician, subsequently Japanese collaborator
Dr Sun Yat-sen (1866-1925), first president of the Republic of China and co-founder of the Guomintang 國民黨|国民党/same as 孫逸仙|孙逸仙
Cai E (1882-1916), originator of the National protection army of 1915
Duan Qirui (1864-1936), commander of Beiyang Army under Yuan Shikai, then politician and powerful warlord
anti-Qing revolutionary party set up in 1904 under Cai Yuanpei 蔡元培/same as 復古會|复古会
opposing Yuan Shikai 袁世凱|袁世凯 in War of national protection 1915-1916/same as 反袁鬥爭|反袁斗争
Chen Duxiu (1879-1942), co-founder of the Chinese Communist Party in 1921
Xiong Chengji (1887-1910), anti-Qing revolutionary and martyr
Chen Tianhua (1875-1905), anti-Qing revolutionary from Hunan, drowned himself in Japan in 1905
Zhang Taiyan (1869-1936), scholar, journalist, revolutionary and leading intellectual around the time of the Xinhai revolution
Zhang Shizhao (1881-1973), revolutionary journalist in Shanghai, then established writer
Cai Yuanpei (1868-1940), liberal educationalist, studied in Germany, president of Peking University 1917-19, minister of education for Guomindang
Xu Shichang (1855-1939), politician associated with the Northern Warlords, president of China in 1921
Kang Youwei (1858-1927), Confucian intellectual, educator and would-be reformer, main leader of the failed reform movement of 1898
